title: Hillary Clinton roasts Republicans who 'can't take the heat' of town halls
text:
Hillary Clinton is chiding lawmakers who "can't take the heat" of town halls during this week's congressional recess after a slew of events where Republicans faced hostile crowds on their home turf.
"If you can't stand the heat, get out of the ... Congress," the former Democratic presidential nominee tweeted on Wednesday. The message included a link to a Kansas City Star editorial about the low number of lawmakers willing to hold town hall events this week. The headline reads: "Cowardly members of Congress should show up and face the public at town-hall meetings."
If you can't stand the heat, get out of the...Congress. https://t.co/TEAXDPEPrt — Hillary Clinton (@HillaryClinton) February 22, 2017 
Clinton's online trolling follows several weeks of protesters and combative participants besieging Republican lawmakers' town halls, where they interact directly with constituents.

This month, Rep. Jason Chaffetz of Utah had a tense town hall with a disruptive crowd who at one point chanted, "Do your job," after a constituent asked about a probe into President Trump 's business interests. Chaffetz later said the disrupters participated in a "paid attempt to bully and intimidate." 
White House press secretary Sean Spicer said Wednesday that the nationwide town hall demonstrations are part of an effort to get "media attention" by a "manufactured base."
Rep. Tom McClintock, R-Calif., was provided a police escort following a town hall in response to a mob of rowdy protesters outside the event.
Even as Clinton teased Republicans on Wednesday, a video posted to social media showed Louisiana Sen. Bill Cassidy being greeted by yelling protesters as he got to an event.

By John Siciliano • 02/22/17 6:05 PM The editorial notes that websites have plans for a disruptive congressional recess. MoveOn.org, for example, has labeled this week "Resistance Week" and provides a guide and resources for organized protests.
It also cites a Salon article that found only 19 Republican members of Congress have traditional town halls scheduled this week, while more than 200 Republicans are choosing not to hold any such events in their home districts.
